page.title: 03PLACE NAMES
page.content: The names of Great and Little Sampford derive from old English words meaning 'a sandy ford'.They were once 'Old' and 'New' Sampford.The ford across the River Pant still exists by-passed by a road and bridge.Bardfield is difficult to interpret but is probrably derived from an old English word,the element 'bard' meaning 'open land colonised by dependant peasants'.The element 'field' is common in this part of Essex and self-explanitory.It occurs also in Finchingfield which means the 'open land of the people of Finc'.The latter is a personal name presumably of a local leader. The River Pant that, with its minor tributaries,links the whole area has a name of Celtic derivation which is rare in Essex.It means'valley river' which is consistent with local geography.
